Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Joshua Townsend of Northwestern University to conduct a research project, entitled "Water storage capacity of planetary interiors," during the summer of 2012 at The University of Ehime Geodynamics Research Centre in Matsuyama, Japan. The host scientist is Dr. Jun Tsuchiya.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to further understanding of what makes a planet habitable for earth-like life.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I went to Japan as an NSF-EAPSI fellow to learn how to do computer simulations of matter under extreme pressure and temperature, because I am interested in the lowest part of the Earths mantle, where pressure approaches 1.3 million atmospheres and temperature exceeds 6000 degrees Farenheit. Before travelling to Japan, my work was focused on conducting experimental x-ray diffraction experiments on high pressure minerals. I was primarily working on a material called "postperovskite" (PPv) because it was discovered after "perovskite" (Pv), and in the Earth PPv is found at higher pressures (and thus lower in the mantle) than Pv. 

There is a popular idea in our modern understanding of how the Earth works, which is that water is necessary for plate tectonics to occur. Over the last several years a lot of surprising discoveries were made which indicated that most of the minerals that occur in the upper layer of the mantle (about 100-660 km depth) could store significant amounts of water in their crystal structures. Furthermore, these hydrous minerals had very different properties than their anhydrous relatives. The number one result of the Earth having a hydrous upper mantle is that plate tectonics may require these hydrous minerals to function because the hydrous minerals melt at lower temperature, and are softer, than their dry partners (hence the popular idea stated above).

However, no experiments or simulations had been done to explore whether or not lower mantle minerals could store water in their structures. My work in Japan was focused on calculating the properties of some plausible hydrous crystal structures for PPv, which occurs only in the deepest part of the mantle, and using that data to compare to seismic measurements. Though I am still working, my preliminary results indicate that PPv may be able to store some water in its structure (I am presently conducting experiments to verify this). This result, if verified, may help explain seismic observations of the lowest mantle which we presently struggle to explain.

On a broader scale, I met many future collaborators during my stay in Japan. Most notably, I forged a lasting professional relationship with my host researcher, which I hope will lead to future work. I also met a professor here in the USA who I will pursue future collaboration with as well. I learned a lot of physics and computer programming, which has fundamentally changed the way I see my career developing. I brought these new techniques back to the USA and now I am planning future work incorporating computational techniques with my advisors.

Thank you NSF for giving me the opportunity to work and study in Japan for 10 weeks, it changed my life in so many good ways!
